title-group.article-title: Preparation and thermal stability of poly(methyl methacrylate)/rice husk silica/triphenylphosphine nanocomposites: assessment of degradation mechanism using model-free kinetics

abstract.p: Nanostructured silica powder was prepared from rice husk (Oryza sativa), an outer covering of rice. Silica was characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy. The silica powder thus prepared was treated with stearic acid for the surface modification. The modified silica was utilized to prepare poly(methyl methacrylate)/modified silica composite films at 1, 5 and 10 wt% loadings by solution casting method, which promises the preparation of homogeneous composites. For comparative analyses, composite films were also made using unmodified silica. Distribution of silica particles in composite film was checked using scanning electron microscopy. Thermal analysis of the samples was carried out using thermogravimetric analyzer followed by model–free multiple–heating rate kinetics. The onset degradation temperature of poly(methyl methacrylate)/silica (modified) composites is found higher than both pure poly(methyl methacrylate) and corresponding poly(methyl methacrylate)/silica (unmodified) composites. This study also reveals the effect of a phosphorus flame retardant additive, triphenylphosphine, on the thermal degradation and flammability behavior of poly(methyl methacrylate) and poly(methyl methacrylate)/silica (modified).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) is a highly transparent thermoplastic, a reasonable substitute to polycarbonate in circumstances when extreme strength is not required. Moreover, it has excellent environmental stability compared to other plastics and is, therefore, often the material of choice for outdoor applications. Nevertheless, it is desirable to improve the thermal stability and flame retardancy of PMMA in order to use it at elevated temperatures while keeping the optical properties unturned. This can be achieved well by a very reliable and preferred method i.e. reinforcement of PMMA matrix with nanosized inorganic fillers.1–8 Many PMMA/silica nanocomposites have recently been reported9–19 and found to exhibit some properties superior to those of neat PMMA. There occurs a remarkable increase in interfacial area due to the small size of fillers which creates a significant volume fraction of interfacial polymer with properties different from the bulk polymer.20

Among the various methods, nanostructured silica can be prepared cheaply from rice husk (Oryza sativa), an outer–covering of rice.21–23 It is mentioned here that rice husk is an agro-waste and is generated in large quantities (18–22 million tons per annum in India) as a main by-product in rice milling industry. Conradt et al.22 have investigated the synthesis of nanostructured silica with 98.7% purity by a simple procedure which involves chemical treatment of rice husk followed by burning it at 600℃ under steam/air atmospheres. Besides, Real et al.23 have prepared 99.5% pure silica from rice husk with a method similar to above using thermogravimetric (TG) analyzer.

The dispersion of silica particles in the polymer matrix has a considerable impact on the properties of nanocomposite. There are a number of ways to improve the dispersion by modifying the hydrophilic surface of silica such as treatment with organosilane agents, titnate coupling agents, fatty acid derivatives,24,25 etc., which possibly increase the compatibility with hydrophobic polymer matrix, thus facilitating the uniform dispersion of silica. Moreover, carboxylate salts of fatty acids with alkyl chain of more than 10 carbon atoms are reported as most efficient surface modifier.24 Lai et al.26 used stearic acid to modify nanosized silica fillers (∼30 nm). Stearic acid reduces the interaction between the silica particles and lowers the volume of agglomerates.

Although polymer/silica nanocomposites exhibit good mechanical properties and thermal stability, yet they do not possess good level of flame-retardancy. Yang et al.27 studied the flammability of PMMA/silica composites and found small increase in limiting oxygen index, and interestingly, composites burned faster than pure PMMA. Therefore, it becomes necessary to use some flame retardant (FR) additives along with nanofillers to get superior flame retardancy. At present, halogen-containing compounds used in synergism with inorganic oxides are the most effective FR, but the current research is looking towards environmentally friendly FRs such as phosphorus-additives.28–30 Therefore, in this study, triphenylphosphine (TPP) is used as an FR additive.31 It would be interesting to study possible synergism between TPP and silica in the presence of PMMA.

Thermal degradation behavior of a polymeric system is a replicate of its flame retardancy and can be best studied using TG technique. In addition, TG kinetics is helpful for understanding the degradation mechanism.32 Now-a-days, model-free multiple-heating rate methods are frequently used for calculating the kinetic parameters.33,34 There are lots of reports that deal with the thermal degradation study of PMMA/silica composites9–17 and many other about the degradation activation energies of PMMA.18–19,35 To the best of our knowledge, there is no report on thermal degradation and flammability behavior of PMMA/rice husk silica/TPP composites. This manuscript deals with eco-friendly and cost-effective preparation of nanosilica from rice husk and its surface modification to further use it in the fabrication of PMMA/modified silica composites and considers the effect of silica, modified silica and TPP on the thermal degradation behavior of PMMA composites using multiple-heating rate TG kinetics. Besides, the manuscript evaluates the thermal stability and flammability behavior of PMMA/modified silica/TPP formulation and the possible interactions and synergism between silica and TPP.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PMMA (molecular weight = 15,000), stearic acid and TPP were supplied by Himedia, India. Chloroform and isopropyl alcohol were purchased from Rankem, India. Rice husk (Variety: Haryana Basmati collection (HBC 19)) was collected from Fatehabad, Haryana, India. Distilled water was used. All materials were used without any purification.

sec.title: Preparation of nanostructured silica
sec.p: Rice husk was washed many times with distilled water to remove adhering soil and dust. Rice husk was then sun dried and powdered using a domestic steel grinder and subsequently passed through 300 mesh sieve. Acid leaching was performed by reflux boiling in 3 M HCl, 3 h, at ratio of 100 g husk/L.21–23 Leached rice husk was given 6–7 washings with distilled water and incinerated to a temperature of 600℃ in TG instrument (Perkin Elmer), at a heating rate of 5℃/min under flowing oxygen atmosphere (50 mL/min).

Silica powder was surface modified with stearic acid, a relatively inexpensive modifier to obtain well-dispersed silica particles in the PMMA matrix.26 As for the surface modification, stearic acid (4 wt% of silica) was firstly added to isopropyl alcohol and the mixture was stirred for about 2 h at room temperature. The silica powder was then added to the combination in order that the silica could bond with stearic acid through acid–base reaction and impart hydrophobic characteristics to the surface of nanosilica.26,36 Silica powder thus obtained was characterized using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques.

sec.title: Preparation of PMMA/silica and PMMA/modified silica composites
sec.p:
The PMMA/modified silica composite films were prepared by a mixture of PMMA solution in chloroform and a dispersion of the modified silica particles in the same solvent. The modified silica content in the composites varied from 1 to 10 wt%. Viscous solutions were then sonicated for 10 min in order to get homogeneous dispersion and subsequently casted on glass plates at room temperature. To remove residual solvent, the samples were dried in vacuum oven at 140℃ for 12 h. The composites are named in the following way: PMMA/MS1, PMMA/MS5, PMMA/MS10 etc., according to the weight percentage of modified silica in the material (Table 1). Similarly, PMMA composites (PMMA/S) using unmodified silica were also prepared at the same loading levels. Besides, TPP (5 wt% of the total weight) was added to PMMA and PMMA/MS5 to study the effect of TPP as FR additive. Table 1.

sec.title: Characterization techniques
sec.p: FTIR spectra were recorded on a MB–3000 ABB spectrophotometer in transmission mode over the frequency range of 4,000–600 cm−1. UV-visible absorption spectra of sample solutions were recorded on T 90 (PG Instruments ltd) UV/Vis spectrometer in the region 900–200 nm. XRD spectra of samples were recorded using a Panalytical’s X’Pert Pro diffractometer operating in the θ–2θ Bragg configuration using Cu Kα radiation. Data were collected at a scan rate of 0.075 θ/min and sampling interval of 0.002°θ. The voltage was set at 45 kV with a 40 mA flux. The SEM pictures of silver-coated selected samples were analyzed by SEM model EVO 50 with an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. TEM micrographs of modified silica were observed using an electron microscope (model: CM200, Philips) at SAIF, IIT, Bombay, India, while micrographs of PMMA/MS5 were carried out with a Technai G2 20 microscope at IIT, Delhi, India. The specimens for TEM were prepared by dispersing the nanocomposite in chloroform by ultrasonic treatment, dropping onto a porous carbon film supported on a copper grid, and then drying in air. TG analyses of all samples including TPP were performed with a Perkin Elmer TG/DTA simultaneous thermal analyzer (horizontal balance mechanism) at a heating rate of 10℃/min and the temperature range was from 50 to 550℃ in flowing dry air atmosphere (20 mL/min). Thermograms of three samples i.e. neat PMMA, PMMA/MS5 and PMMA/MS5/TPP5 were also carried out at 2.5, 5 and 20℃/min for kinetic analysis. Dried alumina powder was used as a reference material and ceramic crucibles were employed to record thermograms. Limiting oxygen index (LOI) values of samples were measured according to ASTM D 2863 using S.A. Associates’s PLATON oxygen index apparatus. The specimens used for the test were of dimensions 100 × 6 × 2 mm3. LOI values are defined by the following equation: LOI(%)=[O2]/([O2]+[N2]) where [O2] and [N2] represent the oxygen and nitrogen concentrations, respectively.

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p:
FTIR spectra of silica as well as modified silica show characteristic absorption peak due to Si–O–Si symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations at 802 and 1100 cm–1, respectively (Figure 1). Unmodified silica exhibits a broad band at 3520 cm–1 owing to stretching vibration of surface silanol (Si–OH) groups.19 On the other hand, modified silica shows two C=O stretching peaks at 1728 and 1589 cm–1 owing to carboxyl group of unreacted stearic acid and carboxylate group resulting from reaction between stearic acid and silanol groups of silica, respectively.11,19,25 Figure 1.
FTIR spectra of silica and modified silica.

sec.title: XRD studies
sec.p:
Figure 2 illustrates the diffractograms of silica, PMMA and PMMA/MS5 in the 2θ range between 15 and 40°. These graphs are without any sharp diffraction peaks thereby confirming the amorphous nature of the samples. Silica powder shows a flat peak at 2θ = 22°. The size of silica particles (D) was estimated by the half width, B, of this peak, using Scherer’s formula23: D=0.89λBcosθ Figure 2.
XRD spectra of silica, PMMA and PMMA/MS5.

With λ = 0.154 nm as the wavelength of Cu Kα radiation and B in radians. By manual evaluation of XRD charts, D = 3.4 nm for the silica powder. In addition, XRD graphs of PMMA/MS5 and PMMA/S5 were alike; for illustration, PMMA/MS5 is given. It can be noticed that the addition of modified silica to the PMMA causes no appreciable change in the graph in line with the work of Ahamad et al.37 Moreover, XRD pattern of PMMA and PMMA/MS5 are blunt which means the addition of nano-silica does not induce any crystallinity in PMMA.

sec.title: SEM and TEM analyses
sec.p:
The TEM images (Figure 3(a)–(d)) show that amorphous silica particles are either alone or in the PMMA/MS5 composite aggregates to form clusters (0.4–1.5 µm), with average size of the secondary silica particle in the cluster about 20 nm in line with the work of Conradt et al.23 who had already reported that silica powder prepared from rice husk contains primary particles of about 1.5 nm, 8–25 nm sized secondaries which in turn form globular clusters of few µm. SEM micrographs (secondary electron (SE) mode) of virgin PMMA and PMMA/MS1 are shown in Figure 4(a) and (b). It can be seen in Figure 4(c) that silica particles are well dispersed in PMMA matrix at 1 wt% loading, however, they form some aggregates along with isolated particles at 10 wt% loading as depicted in Figure 4(d). The Figure also demonstrates that the interaction between PMMA matrix and silica nanoparticles increases with the increase of silica content into PMMA. In case of PMMA/MS10, particle–particle interaction is stronger as compared to polymer–particle interaction, resulting in formation of agglomerates. It is generally stated that the silica particles in a polymer composite exist mainly as agglomerates and are difficult to be dispersed in their original dimensions.38 Thus, the presence of dispersed silica particles indicates that stearic acid treatment has worked but could not bring about the complete dispersion of silica particles. sec.title: UV–visible spectra
sec.p:
UV-visible spectra of PMMA/MS/TPP solutions with different additive content are shown in Figure 5. PMMA shows total transparency in visible region, however, it absorbs UV light at wavelengths below 300 nm. Besides, PMMA/MS5 shows good transparency in visible region because the particles are in nanometer–scale and are well-dispersed in PMMA.15 PMMA/TPP5 and PMMA/TPP5/MS5 are almost transparent in visible region but absorb strongly in UV region owing to the presence of TPP. These optical properties may bestow the PMMA/TPP5/MS5 nanostructured composites with applications in optical devices. Figure 5.
UV-visible spectra of PMMA and PMMA composites.

sec.title: Thermal stability
sec.p:
Effect of nanostructured silica, modified silica and TPP on thermal stability of PMMA. Figure 6 (a)–(d) shows the TG/DTG themograms of PMMA and its composites at a heating rate of 10℃/min under flowing air atmosphere. Thermal degradation of PMMA under air atmosphere can take either depolymerisation or random chain scission route depending on degree of conversion.11,35 PMMA shows a single-step degradation process on TG measurement, which starts from about 280℃ and finishes at about 400℃. Weight loss before 300℃ is due to decomposition of the chain end i.e. from vinylidene end followed by random chain scission of C–C bonds at repeat units.12,13 For better understanding the effect of nanostructured silica on the thermal degradation of PMMA, different characteristic temperatures on TG and DTG curves were determined and are tabulated in Table 1. The data includes To (onset degradation temperature), T10, T20, T50 (temperature values at 10, 20 and 50 wt% loss), Tmax (DTG maxima), char yield at 550℃ and maximum degradation rate (% min–1) at DTG peak temperature. Figure 6.
(a) TG thermograms of PMMA and PMMA/S composites, (b) TG thermograms of PMMA and PMMA/MS composites, (c) TG thermograms of PMMA, TPP, PMMA/TPP5 and PMMA/MS5/TPP5 composites, (d) DTG curves of PMMA, PMMA/TPP5 and PMMA/MS5/TPP5 composites at a heating rate of 10℃/min.

It can be noticed from Table 1 that To improves a little on silica addition, for example, it increase by ∼5℃ for 10 wt% loading except for 1 wt% loading. Similar kind of trends are found for T10, T20, maximum degradation rate and Tmax indicating that the addition of unmodified silica is not much effective to improve the thermal stability of PMMA in PMMA/S10 composite. On the other hand, a clear enhancement in the thermal stability takes place when surface-modified silica is introduced in the matrix. For example, To, T10, T20 and T50 are increased by 10.0, 11.0, 13.4 and 18.9℃, respectively, on the addition of 10 wt% of modified silica to PMMA. DTG curve for PMMA gives single peak with Tmax = 322℃ while PMMA/MS10 shows two DTG peaks at 327 and 354℃ with low degradation rate than neat PMMA indicating that the presence of modified silica extends the thermal degradation of PMMA to higher temperatures. It is well documented that the presence of thermally stable silica increases the degradation temperature by shifting the weight loss to higher temperatures.13,14 The char yield (at 550℃) of pure PMMA is zero while that for PMMA/MS composites are 0.9, 6.3 and 13.3%, respectively, for 1, 5 and 10 wt% silica (modified) loading, which are interestingly higher than the theoretical ones.14 This might be induced by the formation of network of PMMA chains and silica moieties which may restrain the movement of free radicals and their attack on PMMA to cause chain scissoring leading to higher char residues.14,15 Appreciable enhancement in the thermal stability in case of PMMA/MS as compared to PMMA/S may be attributed to the better dispersion of modified silica which leads to the availability of comparatively larger surface area of silica for the interaction with polymer.

PMMA/TPP5 decomposed in two steps; weight loss in the first step (150 to 280℃) corresponds to the evaporation of TPP (Tmax = 201.7℃) as it matches well with TPP degradation range (Figure 6(c)) whereas the second step (280 to 400℃) relates to the decomposition of PMMA with Tmax = 356.1℃ (for neat PMMA Tmax = 322℃) indicating that the presence of TPP in PMMA/TPP5 delays the decomposition of PMMA. Importantly, maximum degradation rate corresponding to PMMA degradation peak for PMMA/TPP5 is smaller as compared to neat PMMA. Besides, PMMA/MS5/TPP5 shows more stability as compared to PMMA/TPP5 as indicated by suppressed DTG peak corresponding to TPP evaporation and more weight (%) at temperatures greater than 340℃ possibly owing to the solid phase cross-linking and aromatization reactions, which occur in intercalated polymer–phosphorus compounds.39,40 It is commonly thought that phosphorus FR additive mainly works in gaseous phase owing to the formation of phosphorus free radicals that act as free radical traps around the flame, however, the mechanism of FR changes to the condensed phase when it is intercalated into two dimensions structure of inorganic compound in combination with polymer.39 Thus, the synergetic effect of TPP and silica led to improved thermal stability of PMMA through the formation of intercalated structures with TPP and silica.

sec.title: Kinetic study
sec.p:
We have chosen three samples i.e. neat PMMA, PMMA/MS5 and PMMA/MS5/TPP5 for comparative kinetic studies. Thermograms were observed at four different linear heating rates and are shown in Figure 7(a)–(c). As expected, the slower heating rate gives better differentiation of the degradation process and provides early start to degradation reactions. A reduced thermal lag is the core mechanism responsible for the better differentiation. Figure 7.
(a) TG thermograms of PMMA, (b) TG thermograms of PMMA/MS5, (c) TG thermograms of PMMA/MS5/TPP5 at different heating rates.

Friedman41 and Kissinger–Akahira–Sunose (KAS)42,43 methods are used to calculate degradation activation energies of PMMA samples as per the recommendations made by ICTAC kinetics committee (2011)44 and the main equations of these methods are given in Table 2. In these equations, β is the heating rate, t is time, T is temperature, n is the reaction order, R is the universal gas constant, A is the pre-exponential factor, α is the degree of conversion and E is the activation energy. As an example, the Friedman41 iso-conversional plot for PMMA/MS5/TPP5 is shown in Figure 8, while Figure 9 shows the specific results of application of KAS method42,43 using PMMA/MS5 as example, respectively. The evaluated degradation activation energies at varying degrees of conversion of the samples are shown in Figures 10 and 11. Only those values are shown whose plots have good regression coefficients (correlation coefficient > 0.95), rest are neglected for the sake of accurate comparison. The results calculated by iso–conversional methods presents a general trend of activation energy while going from lower to higher degrees of conversion for each sample. Figure 8.

The degradation activation energy, E, of PMMA shows appreciable variation with the progress of reaction i.e. α values. This dependence of E on α is consistent with the occurrence of two degradation mechanism i.e. random chain scission and unzipping reaction.35 The E values calculated by Friedman method corresponding to initial degradation (α = 0.05) equals to 169 ± 22.4 kJ/mol indicating initial degradation of PMMA took place via random chain scission mechanism (Figure 10).35 This statement is derived from the work of Peterson et al.35 who had reported that random chain scissoring of PMMA degradation is associated with E value of ∼200 kJ/mol and unzipping pathway corresponds to an E value of ∼100 kJ/mol. The activation energy decreases with increasing α values and reaches to minimum (124 ± 9/129 ± 12.4 kJ/mol (Friedman/KAS)) at α = 0.5 suggesting an increasing role of alternative low-energy unzipping mechanism to the overall degradation rate. After this point, the E value shows regular increase with increasing degrees of conversion and reaches to maximum at the completion of degradation process (271 ± 24/192 ± 21 kJ/mol (Friedman/KAS)). This increase in E may be caused by the increasing contribution of random scissoring pathway. Peterson et al.35 had reported a similar kind of E–α dependence for PMMA i.e. E decreased from 200 kJ/mol to a minimum of about 150 kJ/mol at α = 0.55, then increased to a maximum of about 200 kJ/mol at the completion of degradation.

A similar kind of E–α dependence is found for PMMA/MS5. The E value at α = 0.02 falls in the range 166 ± 21.6–183 ± 7.4 kJ/mol which is higher than virgin PMMA indicating that the composite is thermally more stable than neat matrix, however, for α > 0.02, PMMA/MS5 shows lower E values as compared to PMMA. Pantaleon et al.18 had reported lower degradation activation energy for PMMA/silica than PMMA whereas Hu et al.19 have found higher E values for silica composites. Silica act as insulator and mass–transport barrier to the volatile products formed during the degradation resulting in higher initial E value, however, after a certain degree of conversion, this heat barrier acts in a reverse manner i.e. the accumulated heat by the silica could be released, acting as new heat source along with outside source, causing an acceleration to degradation as reflected in lower E values.45 Further, the E values for PMMA/MS5 firstly decrease with increasing degrees of conversion upto α = 0.3 and then remain almost constant around 100/110 kJ/mol (Friedman/KAS) upto α = 0.7, indicating that PMMA/MS5 degrades via unzipping mechanism during the conversion range 0.3 < α < 0.7.35 The presence of silica particles favor the bond cleavage through low-energy unzipping pathway resulting in formation of chain ends and free radicals that favor thermal degradation.15,18 The E values show small increment for α > 0.7 until the completion of the reaction and reaches to a maximum of 139.7 kJ/mol at α = 0.9 suggesting that at the completion of degradation both the mechanisms have their equal contribution toward the overall degradation rate.35 Thus, the presence of nanostructured silica causes an appreciable variation in activation energy by shifting the degradation pathway from random scission to unzipping.18

The degradation E values calculated for PMMA/MS5/TPP5 using Friedman method are not in agreement with the values determined by KAS method. Noticeably, lower E values are observed for PMMA/MS5/TPP5 than PMMA/MS5 during α < 0.7/0.5 (KAS/Friedman) implying that TPP catalyses the degradation process and favors the production of non-flammable products,39 however, above this conversion limit PMMA/MS5/TPP5 corresponds to higher E values than PMMA/MS5 possibly due to the formation of thermally stable intercalated polymer–phosphorus structure which promotes the solid state cross-linking and aromatization reactions.39,40,46 This structure may stop the propagation of radicals and thus restrict the further degradation of composite. Hence, the synergetic effect of TPP and silica lead to improved thermal stability at higher degrees of conversion via intercalation of TPP and silica.

sec.title: LOI testing
sec.p:
The LOI test results are summarized in Table 3. The results show that the addition of silica to PMMA increases the LOI values though slightly. As discussed in previous sections, silica plays the roles of radical trapping and polymer chain mobility restriction during the degradation process of polymer and as a result LOI values are increased. In addition, it can be seen that the incorporation of just 0.59 wt% phosphorus increases the LOI of PMMA from 17.5 to 19.7%, indicating a reduction in flammability. The PMMA/MS5/TPP5 nanocomposite shows an obvious synergy with an LOI of 20.5%. The improved flame retardancy of the PMMA/MS5/TPP5 system may be attributed to the enhanced barrier properties of their hybrid and also to superior char production. Table 3.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Nanostructured silica from rice husk and subsequently its composite with PMMA were successfully prepared via solution casting method. Composite films were also prepared using surface-modified silica and TPP. SEM analyses points toward a medium level dispersion of modified silica in PMMA/MS5 film. The particle size of silica is found to be ∼3 nm as calculated using XRD data, which is supported well by TEM images.

TG and kinetic analyses revealed that PMMA/modified silica composites are thermally more stable than virgin PMMA. Besides, modified silica gives better enhancement in the stability in comparison to unmodified. It is generally assumed that FR mechanism of TPP is restricted to vapor phase, however, it is found that in the presence of silica (PMMA/MS5/TPP5) it changes to condensed phase as appeared from less weight loss during evaporation range of TPP, increased weight (%) above 340℃ in comparison to PMMA/TPP5 and LOI values owing to the synergetic effect of silica and TPP. TPP catalyses the initial degradation of PMMA/MS5/TPP5 as indicated from lower E values than PMMA/MS5 during α < 0.7/0.5 (KAS/Friedman) resulting in formation of thermally stable intercalated polymer–phosphorus–silica structure which restricts the further degradation as suggested by higher E values than PMMA/MS5 for at higher degrees of conversion (α > 0.7/0.5).
PMMA reinforced with modified nanosilica presents improved thermal stability and would open new prospects for reinforcement of polymer materials by rice husk’s silica.
